div.p: Peace to you all who are in Christ Jesus, etc.

A friendly greeting with all due respect, love, and goodness, especially to you, dear lord and brother. My request and desire is for you to hear the best from me; if I can serve you in any way, whether small or great, I am inclined and willing, etc. I am informed, dear lord, that Lord Lorenz Meyer of Glarus has passed away; I served him faithfully while I was fulfilling my preaching duties in Romanshorn, where he owed me 10 b and 7[?] in loans.

He sent books to Ludwig in Thun, and in the meantime, I bought 4 ells of cloth from Hans Brüdermann in St. Gallen and gave him the money for it; they cost 17 b. In all this, he sent me a testament, which cost 10 b; he always indicated to me and promised to send it to me, but it never happened. He still owes me 24 b.

My request to you, as a gracious lord and brother, is that you help me with this, as my lord's wife, children, and goods have been taken, and I am sending this through this messenger to save costs; for I am a poor preacher with many small, unprovided-for children, otherwise, I would not pursue this matter. My request to you is that you do the best on my behalf.
May the city be worthy of your honor, etc. Gratia domini Iesu Christi sit vobiscum.
Given on the 12th day of September in the year 64.
Your faithful and willing Georg Mönhart, preacher in Kirchberg in Toggenburg.
To the honorable and highly learned lord, Master Heinrich Bullinger, preacher of a praiseworthy Christian community, my especially gracious lord. Zurich 64.
